text:
My name is Alyson
Gounden Rock, and I

am a PhD candidate
at Desautels Faculty
of Management at McGill.

And my advisor, my wonderful
advisor, Brian, is here.

I'm also currently a
visiting PhD student

at MIT Sloan School's
Institute for Work

and Employment Research
with Erin Kelly.

I'm presenting to you
evidence from my thesis

that within jobs, tasks
contribute to gender wage
inequality.

Now, what we know about
gender wage inequality

comes mostly from two
different factors,

sets of factors at the industry
level and at the job level.

Together, they make up about
half of the gender wage gap.

So about 40% of the gender
wage gap is still unexplained.

And one place that we
really haven't looked at
is within jobs themselves.

We've always assumed, in fact,
or for a long time assumed

that were we to compare a man
and a woman in the same job

that we would not find any
evidence of the gender pay gap.

There has been a paper-- a set
of papers in the last year that

have shown us across many
different occupations
that it does exist.

There is some gender
inequality that

is substantial within
jobs themselves.

But the research design was
not able to speak to mechanism,
and so we don't know why.

And that's what I'm hoping
to do in my research.

One way that we can look
into jobs themselves

is to look at the tasks
that make up a job.

And so what I'm
doing in my thesis

is to look at the types of
tasks that are in a job.

It's been really
hard to find out

if tasks contribute to
gender wage inequality

because if we were to do
that, we would need first

to have task data, but
across many individuals

and for many jobs,
as well as pairing it
with individual wage data.
That's been super hard to find.

So imagine my excitement when
I found a source of task, job,
and wage data.

In the population of US
union staff-- so not nurses,

not firefighters, but the
staff who support them--

about 100,000 unique workers
in union locals across time.

And the exciting part
for this research

is that there is a within
job description of five

different task types, and that's
what I'm using in my research.

With it, I'm able to
answer this question.

Within the same job,
does performing only one

versus more than
one type of task

contribute to gender
wage inequality?

Now that's pretty abstract, so
let's think of a job together.
A secretary.

And what I'm able to do with my
data, which is very powerful,

is that within
individual analysis--

so I can take the
same person who's

a secretary in one year
with only one type of job

and compare them to
themselves in a different year

in which they have more
than one type of task.

And this can cause for
everything seen and unseen,

which is unusual
and very powerful.

My main findings
are that men are

more likely than women
to have a job with more
than one type of task.

And having a job with
more than one type of task

is linked to having higher
wages than having only one type.

And that's about 7% of the
mean wage in the sample.

And what I find too, which
perhaps surprises us, maybe

doesn't, is that the returns
are different for men
and for women.
And it's about a 3% difference.

So men have about $3,700
and women about $2,500.

So my contributions are
to these academic areas,

but also, the one
thing I want you

to take and disseminate
and remember from my talk

is that tasks within jobs
contribute substantially
to gender wage inequality.

It has implications
for employers.
How we allocate tasks matters.

Employees, the tasks we
have in our job matters.

And for policymakers,
we can now start

to think about, what
are the policies
that we need to imagine?
Thank you very much.
[APPLAUSE]
